headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Priscilla Presley Contests Validity of Will; Screen Time Linked to Cognitive Impairment; Renewed Debate over Binge Versus Weekly Television Viewing. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Priscilla Presley is now disputing the validity of her daughter's will. She was removed as a co-trustee back in 2016 and replaced by Lisa Marie's children. But Priscilla's lawyers now say there are several issues with the document. They say Priscilla's name was spelled. Lisa Marie's signature doesn't look right. As you know, Lisa Marie is Elvis Presley's only child. She was laid to rest at his Graceland estate earlier this month.Joining us now to talk about this is CNN's chief business correspondent, and "EARLY START" anchor, Christine Romans. OK, so a living trust is basically this form of a way to control your assets while you're still alive.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CHIEF BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes. Right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: What is it - I mean what is the dispute here over?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So, the issue here is that Priscilla Presley didn't know in 2016 that this - the -- the trustees had been changed upon the death of Lisa Marie. It wasn't notarized. That's one of the things she's concerned about. She wasn't alerted, and that is required ironclad part of this trust is that she must be notified of any changes to this document. And she wasn't. So that's why her lawyers have petitioned the court to see if this 2016 amendment to her will is actually legal and valid.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Wow. I mean it - it -- how long could this take, do you think?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So, I was looking at the Michael Jackson estate. That took 12 years to settle. Michael Jackson was heavily in debt when he died. And what's interesting to me, by the time they settled that whole estate, it was profitable again. It was like four times as profitable as it had been.So, you've got an estate here that includes a 15 percent stake in Elvis Presley Enterprises, Graceland, the mansion, which Pricilla, at one time had said, is it - or Lisa Marie had said is absolutely 100 percent mine. It will always be mine, Graceland. It will always be. And when it is no longer mine, it will be my children's. And that is that. And now we are at the place where her children are named in this will as her trustees now, and her own mother is disputing it.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Is not.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So, it's granddaughters and a grandmother together over the future of what is a very complicated, complicated fortune.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: And you mentioned Michael Jackson because, you know, they had that connection. But often, I mean, when you look at -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Most of the folks who die, a lot of them die in debt, and then -

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Because they're not spending it, quite often, within months or years, they end up - you know, the estates just go up in value exponentially.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Elvis Presley made much more money in death, frankly, than he did in life.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: In life.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: You know, that has been a brand that has been just, you know, just sterling.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Michael Jackson, Whitney Houston, on and on and on.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Four-day work week. Let's switch gears here.So, Maryland lawmakers -

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Are propose this bill for a four-day workweek, but you can't force a private company to do that, right? It would be all the federal agencies - or state agencies?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: No, but you can - no, it's about tax incentives. It's giving tax incentives to companies to try it. And this is inspired by this four-day workweek global pilot that we have reported on here on this program that found productivity went up, burnout went down, people didn't have to commute as much, they saved money. I mean had very good results of this global pilot.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Uh-huh. ROMANS

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I suppose it would incent, well, more hiring, right, because like you need to have the same number of doctors. They need three anchors when we take Friday's off.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, four-day workweek, bosses, are you listening?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Look -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You'd have to hire replacements for some necessary jobs.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's so productive (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: But it's -- it's a response to the great resignation. I mean people seemed - people seemed to really like it. They do all of their personal business on whatever day they have off of the week. You don't have the pressure and the stress to go to your kids -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Wait, Kaitlan doesn't want it. Is that what you said?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I said I'd be bored. Sorry, guys.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'd be bored too, on a beach.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I'd hear less complaints from my kid saying, why do you go to work every morning?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: But sales rose at the companies that tried this. And sales and profits rose.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, interesting.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So, it turned out it was profitable for the companies. It wasn't just nice, it was profitable.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Love that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Romans.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Always a pleasure. Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: An historic match-up. Two black quarterbacks will play against each other for the first time on football's biggest stage ahead of the Chiefs versus Eagles, Mahomes versus Hurts showdown. Bears quarterback Justin Fields spoke to our very own Coy Wire about how significant this moment is for the future of the NFL. Watch.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JUSTIN FIELDS, CHICAGO BEARS QUARTERBACK
utterances.sentences: I'm excited for it. I know those guys are going to be, you know, hyped up and, you know, ready to play. But, you know, it's definitely a big moment for, you know, a lot of back, you know, young QBs coming up. And just, you know, being -- having them inspire them, and, you know, maybe, you know, they're saying to themselves that, you know, that can be me one day.So just, you know, being able to see that, you know, if you're a young kid out there, a young black quarterback, being able to see that and kind of say, wow, like, you know, it's actually happening, you know, that could be me one day. So, it's definitely awesome to see for sure. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, if Mahomes wins against the Eagles, he will be the first black quarterback with multiple Super Bowl wins. And if the Eagles beat the Chiefs, well, Hurts would become the fourth black quarterback to win a Super Bowl joining Mahomes, Doug Williams, and Russell Wilson.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: How much tablet time is too much? A new study finds your child's academic success may start with their screen time, or lack of screentime, when they are infants.Our medical correspondent Dr. Tara Narula joins us now. Infants. DR. TARA NARULA, CNN MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: Infants. Yes. It's amazing that so many parents are giving tablets to kids who are less than 12 months old.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's a babysitter.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean it's become so much a part of our culture. We have kids. You know that kids want to use screens. And so how do we navigate this? And I think this study really gives us an idea of just how potentially damaging this can be.And so in this study, they basically looked at around a little over 400 children and they assessed their screen time as early as 12 months. And on average it was about two hours, which is a lot. And then they followed them for about nine years and they found that once the kids reached about nine years, they actually showed signs of decreased executive functioning and attention. What is executive functioning? It's really how we focus, how we pay attention, multitask, make decisions, plan. It's so critical to our professional academic success, our ability to mentally and emotionally regulate ourselves and function. So, these are really critical skills. And the other interesting part of this study is that around 18 months, some of these children had an EEG, which is a way of assessing brain function, and they already saw early changes on the EEG. Now, you can't definitively prove that it's the screen time that was associated with this and not something else in the home environment in that -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Correlation is not necessarily causation.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Exactly. So maybe parents who gave their kids screens, there was something else going on at home too.But the bottom line is, when a kid is looking at a screen at that young of an age, they're not -- their brain isn't developing in the normal way. They're not able to learn with that face-to-face interaction back and forth that they get with a parent. The hands on, the socialization. That 2D just doesn't cut it. And so this really fits with the American Academy of Pediatrics recommendations that under 18 months children should not be using screens unless they're using it to video chat with a family member. And then from ages two to five, it should be limited to less than one hour.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: So, it's hard to do. I have kids. It's hard to tell them to put the screen down, but really, really important.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We don't have kids, so, we don't have to deal with that for now.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: You might someday.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Every Sunday when I get my screen time, though, from iPhone that sends you the - Apple sends you your screentime. I'm like, oh, my God, I'm on my screen so much.But all this also ties into the other topic that we're talking about this morning, which is learning loss for children.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You know, my mom's a fourth grade teacher. And this is because of Covid. And she saw this a lot. A lot of families where people said,  oh, well, your kids at home, they can do their school work on their computer or whatever and it was a real struggle for a lot of kids.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Yes, and it's just not the same. And that's what this other study that we're talking about showed. It was an international study that looked at about 15 countries, 42 studies, they put together all the data, and they, in fact, found that kids had about a 35 percent learning loss compared to a normal year. This deficit started early. It has persisted. So we haven't made up for it. It affected disproportionately children from disadvantaged backgrounds. And also it seemed like the losses were greater in math versus English or reading or other language skills.But, you know, how do we catch up? At this point, I think, is really the question. And so some of the researchers suggest after school programs, summer programs, lengthening the school day, potentially online or learning apps as well. But really tough.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All things I support.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I just do. Longer school day? Longer into the summer.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But, controversial, I know.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Doc.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And a new HBO drama, "The Last of Us," is renewing the debate, which is better, binge or weekly watching? We will discuss.(COMMERCIAL BREAK) (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm taking you with me. We can just keep our histories to ourselves. We don't tell anyone about your condition.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CHLOE MELAS, CNN ENTERTAINMENT REPORTER
utterances.sentences: We've been talking about it for the last hour.ALAN SEPINWALL, CHIEF TV CRITIC, "ROLLING STONE": Yes.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: So I'm going to let him take this one first because he has TV critic in the title of his name. So I'll let you go first.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: I would say, in general, there's a handful of shows that are better if you binge them. But, for the most part, I think TV's better weekly. It's better episodically. I think this episode of "The Last of Us" is a great example of that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You're just old school, Alan.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: I'm - yes, I'm old and old school. But also, like, you get to spend a whole week thinking about this show, talking about it. You're seeing it on the same night as everybody else is seeing it. So, when somebody does something really special, it still feels like an event, even in this really fragmented state of television where there's too many shows. You don't get that with a binge. This would be the third episode you would watch in a weekend, and then you would move on and you would forget about it.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: And everyone is talking about the last episode being one of the best hours of television possibly ever.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: Yes. And if you look at what our CNN critic, sorry, Brian Lowry is saying, he says it's absolutely spectacular. And he's very, you know -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Critical.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: He doesn't like a lot of things. Sorry, Brian. But, you know, it's - it's - it makes me want to speed up to this - to the third episode.Now, I've been very introspective this morning about what I watch on television. And I have -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: I have discovered that I too am an old lady. Everything - everything -

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: We all are old ladies.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: Everything that I like to watch on television is episodic. I will tell you what I watch. There's a theme here. "Billions," Showtime, episodic. "Succession," love "Succession," HBO, episodic.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Love.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: All of these shows are about money. I need it."White Lotus," HBO.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: I mean, come on. I mean I'm obsessed with Jennifer Coolidge. We talked at the Golden Globes. And I will tell you now, she's upset, too, that she's -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Dead. That she died.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: She is. Yes. She's (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. She told me this. She told me this. And I - I know. And then "This is Us," sorry, got to say it, I think it's great television, NBC.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Is that on - I think they were done.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: It's over now -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: But I'm telling you like everything I like is appointment television. And I think that what it goes to show you is that people like communal moments together.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: And sharing this and talking about it and anticipating it together.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Does that count for the original "Law and Order" that I watch over and over and over every single day? It's (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: Turns out procedural TV is still something that's really popular.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. You've got all these hits. I mean Peacock just launched one that Rian Johnson and Natasha Lyonne are doing called "Poker Face," like the classic '70s style mystery of the week. So, it's real - it's still really fun if you just watch one episode and then wait and get the next one a week or so later.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: How has no one mentioned "Sopranos."

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: I mean -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Remember.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: If you get me talking about "Sopranos," we'll just be here all week.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I just - OK, so I'm old lady too, which is actually what Luca, my son, calls me, but -

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: My son Luke - my son Luke calls me old lady.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Because we're old ladies -

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: My young producer had to e-mail me about this last night. She's like, personally, as much as I love binge watching, I also love having something to look forward to each week and discuss. And I think she, a young viewer, nailed it.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Because when it's all binge, then if you don't watch it right away you're going to find out on social media what's going on.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: But we will say, though, adversely, some of the shows that you can binge, like "Stranger Things" on Netflix, quite possibly one of Netflix's biggest hits you were saying.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: And, you know, also "Wednesday Adams" on Netflix was incredibly popular.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: Yes. That was very popular. Hulu had a show called "The Bear," which I think would have gotten lost in the shuffle if you ever watched one at a time.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: But because the algorithm would keep playing it for you, I think that really caught on back in the summer. So, sometimes a binge can work. I just think, for the most part, weekly episodic is still superior.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: And I think that the other thing that he spoke to me about, which I had never heard about before until this morning, and when I tell you, like, we've already -- I already interviewed him this morning for like an hour.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: We're best friends.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: There is decision fatigue, which is the story of my life at night, where there's so much to watch on some of these streaming services and I need something - I need order in my life. I need to be able to know what to watch.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, you need to watch "Law and Order" then. So like, shon (ph) tong (ph).

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: I need to know what to watch every week. I can't have all of these options, you know, it can be too much.Now, binging went up during the pandemic.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: You know, and that is still the more popular form of watching television.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I feel like I got to the end of like streaming during the pandemic, and I've seen a lot of it. And I won't mention which, you know, streaming service.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: What are you watching right now?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You - honestly, look, you know, you know I know I love Jennifer Coolidge and whatever. I watch a lot of Apple.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Not Apple TV, but YouTube.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: And the reality TV is episodic.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Can I just - just real quick, what it is -- why are people upset about the introduction of this gay character, at least people figuring it out in the final episode, of course?

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, I definitely have seen a lot of excitement. A lot of people very sort of refreshingly were warmed by how beautiful this love story was. But I think there's a certain segment of the gamer audience in particular who is just in denial about this. My understanding in the game is that the character is very clearly gay, but it's a little bit implied, and here it was very explicit. And, for them, they just don't want it. And it's unfortunate.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But it made for a really special hour of TV.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: Yes. COLLINS

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: Maybe the best ever, right?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: I cried multiple times.

utterances.speaker: MELAS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Because of that episode?

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: It's just amazing. Nick Offerman, Murray Bartlett are incredible. It's a beautifully told love story in the space of a single hour of television.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, guys. We cried and we laughed and we got to learn about each other.

utterances.speaker: SEPINWALL
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'm talking about this moment right now. Thank you very much, Chloe Melas and Alan Sepinwall.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, guys.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.And straight ahead here on CNN, why some car insurers are refusing to cover certain Hyundai and Kia models.
